issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect a public method named singFarmSong() in Farm (task description and template declare/expect singFarmSong()). The solution implementation, however, provides a method named playFarmSong() instead of singFarmSong(). This name/signature mismatch is structural: code (e.g., Main in template/problem examples) and automated tests that call singFarmSong() will not find it in the solution, and students comparing solution and template will be confused about which method to implement/call.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem/template by renaming playFarmSong() to singFarmSong(), or add a public singFarmSong() method that delegates to the existing playFarmSong(). Ensure the method name and signature exactly match the one described in the problem and present in the template (public void singFarmSong()).

issues.description: The problem statement and the template require/expect a Farm method named singFarmSong(). The template repository includes a stub public void singFarmSong() (template_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java). In the solution repository, however, the public method that plays the song is named playFarmSong() (solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Farm.java). This naming mismatch (singFarmSong() vs. playFarmSong()) breaks the direct mapping from the exercise requirements to the provided solution API and would confuse students about which method to implement or call; the solution's Main still contains a (commented) call to farm.singFarmSong(), further demonstrating the inconsistency.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the public API name across artifacts. Rename the solution's playFarmSong() method to singFarmSong(), or add a singFarmSong() wrapper that delegates to playFarmSong(), and update any calls (e.g., Main) accordingly. This keeps the method name the same as specified in the problem and the template and removes the mapping confusion for students.
